title: Introduction
description: JavaScript is a versatile, high-level programming language primarily used to make web pages interactive and dynamic. It allows developers to create engaging user interfaces, handle user input, and communicate with servers. JavaScript is an essential language for front-end web development, working alongside HTML and CSS. Originally developed in 1995 by Brendan Eich, JavaScript has grown to power websites, web apps, mobile apps, and even server-side applications with Node.js. With its widespread adoption, modern JavaScript supports advanced features such as object-oriented programming, asynchronous operations, and functional programming concepts.
dialogue: A wooden sign creaks at the town gate.
Something here once made everything alive.

title: Console Output
description: The console is a tool in your browser or coding environment where JavaScript can display messages. Using console.log(), you can print text, numbers, or variables to the console. This is useful for debugging, checking your code's output, and learning how your program behaves step by step. You can call console.log() as many times as needed to display multiple messages. In this lesson, you will learn how to print messages on separate lines to communicate clearly with your program and understand the flow of execution.

title: Variables
description: Variables are like containers where you can store information in your program. In JavaScript, you can create variables using `let`, `const`, or `var`. `let` allows you to store values that can change later, `const` is for values that stay constant, and `var` is the older way to declare variables. Variables can store different types of data, such as text (strings), numbers, or true/false values (booleans). Printing variables to the console using `console.log()` helps you see their values and debug your program. In this lesson, you will practice creating variables to store your hero's name, score, and online status, and display them.
task: Create three variables named playerName, score, and isOnline. Assign them the values 'Nova', 120, and true. Then print all three variables to the console on separate lines.

title: Data Types
description:
In JavaScript, every value has a type. The most common types you'll use are: 

- **Strings**: sequences of characters, like text. Always wrapped in quotes (`"Hello"`).
- **Numbers**: numeric values, like 42 or 3.14, used for counting or math operations.
- **Booleans**: true/false values, used for decision-making.

Understanding data types is essential because it helps your program know how to process and store information correctly. In this lesson, you'll practice creating variables of different types and printing them to see their values in the console.
task: Create three variables named userName, lives, and hasKey. Assign them the values 'Aria', 3, and false, respectively. Then print each variable on a separate line.
hints: Use console.log() to print each variable.

title: Functions
description:
Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform a specific task. Instead of writing the same code multiple times, you can define a function once and call it whenever you need it. Functions help keep your code organized and easy to read.

In this lesson, you'll learn how to define a function using the `function` keyword, and how to call it to execute its instructions.
task: Create a function named `showMessage` that prints 'Welcome!' to the console. Then call this function twice to see the message printed two times.
hints: Use the `function` keyword to define a function.
Call the function by its name followed by parentheses `()`.

title: Parameters
description: Parameters allow functions to receive input values. Instead of hardcoding data inside a function, you can pass arguments when calling it. This makes your functions more flexible and reusable. Parameters act like placeholders for real values that are provided later. In this lesson, you will pass a name into a function and use it to personalize a greeting.
task: Create greet(name) that prints 'Hello ' + name. Call with 'Jet'.

title: Return Values
description: Functions can send data back using the `return` keyword. A return value allows you to store or use the result of a function elsewhere in your program. Without `return`, a function only performs an action. With `return`, it produces a value. In this lesson, you'll create a function that calculates a product and returns the result.
task: Create multiply(x,y) returning product. Print multiply(4,5).

title: Arrow Functions
description: Arrow functions are a modern and shorter way to write functions in JavaScript. They use the `=>` syntax and are commonly used in modern applications. Arrow functions are especially useful for quick operations and callbacks. In this lesson, you'll rewrite a traditional function using arrow syntax.
task: Create arrow function welcome(user) printing 'Welcome ' + user. Call with 'Jet'.

title: Arrays
description: Arrays allow you to store multiple values inside a single variable. Each value in an array has an index, starting from 0. Arrays are useful for managing lists of data like names, numbers, or items. In this lesson, you will create an array and access a specific item using its index.
task: Create fruits array and print second item.

title: Array Methods
description: JavaScript provides built-in methods to manipulate arrays. Methods like `push()`, `pop()`, `shift()`, and `unshift()` allow you to add or remove items. These tools make arrays powerful and dynamic. In this lesson, you'll remove the last item of an array using `pop()`.
task: Create [1,2,3], remove last item using pop(), print array.

title: Objects
description: Objects store data using key-value pairs. They are used to represent real-world entities like users, cars, or products. Each value is accessed using a key. Objects help organize related information into a single structure. In this lesson, you'll create an object and access one of its properties.
task: Create car with brand 'Tesla', year 2024. Print year.

title: Object Methods
description: Objects can contain not only data but also functions. When a function is inside an object, it is called a method. Methods allow objects to perform actions. In this lesson, you'll create an object with a method and call it to execute its behavior.
task: Create robot with speak() printing 'Beep!'. Call it.

title: Selecting Elements
description: The DOM (Document Object Model) represents the structure of an HTML page. JavaScript can interact with the DOM to read or change content. Selecting elements allows you to target specific parts of a webpage. In this lesson, you'll use `document.getElementById()` to select an element and display its text.
task: Select element with id 'message' and print textContent.

title: Modifying Content
description: After selecting an element, JavaScript can modify its content. Changing `textContent` allows you to update what users see on the page. This makes web pages dynamic and interactive. In this lesson, you'll change the text of an HTML element.
task: Select h1 and change text to 'Hi!'.

title: Event Listeners
description: Event listeners allow JavaScript to respond to user actions like clicks, typing, or hovering. The `addEventListener()` method waits for an event and executes code when it happens. This is how websites become interactive. In this lesson, you'll respond to a button click.
task: Add click listener to button printing 'Clicked!'.

title: Dynamic Styling
description: JavaScript can modify CSS styles dynamically. By accessing the `style` property of an element, you can change colors, sizes, or layout instantly. This allows visual changes without editing CSS files directly. In this lesson, you'll change the color of an element using JavaScript.
task: Select h1 and change color to red.

title: JavaScript Final Exam
task: Create function that adds two numbers and print result of 5 and 7.
